ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to use python and evaluate political strategies with data
a little more about how data is used in campaigns and what campaign strategies have impact; sort of how to use python? but also lots is just looking stuff up
I learned the basics of Python in jupyter and how to analyze data, mostly from election campaigns.
I was able to learn how to do basic code functions in pandas.
I learned how to use Python. I also learned about elections, campaigns, and how data is connected to both of those! I also learned how to analyze a dataset.
Basic Python skills and political data analysis

This course provides an overview of basic data science fundamentals, specifically applied to political campaigns. It begins with an introductory module to Python, which is very helpful to those who have little to no coding experience, and then folds in concepts of political campaigning that can be tested with the data science methods introduced in class.
How to apply statistics in a political science setting
Learned how to use Python and all about politics
I learned how political campaigns use data analysis to help their campaign measures. I learned how to code in Python to make graphs, analyze data sets, and find accuracy, precision, and recall.
I learned about how political campaigns utilize data to mobilize voters, and I also gained a basic understanding of how to implement such strategies through Python.
An expansion on the computing language of Python, as well as its specialized use in political science, political campaigns in particular.
Data analysis, data interpretation, data discrepancies, python coding, and much more.
I learned how to code in Python and how data science interacts with political campaigns.
How to code in python

Overall, this class helped to develop insights and knowledge on the process of political campaigns and the usage of data in understanding election and voting trends. The most important skill I developed in this course was learning how to understand and code in Python. By learning this valuable skill,I was able to create long statistical analyses and the like to better understand campaigns.
I developed a solid introductory background in Python and how data analytics can be used in political campaigns.
Learning Python for Data Science skills and general political campaigning tips.

This skill develops initial Python skills for those interested in conducting data science in the field of political science. Aside from that, you also learn about important statistical concepts which would help with both research and analysis moving forward, whether that's throughout your time at Yale or after. You learn to work within Jupyter notebook and you build some basic foundations for further instruction in coding-based data science.
I learned how to code in python and I learned more about political campaign strategies
I definitely know much more about how campaigns use (or should use, or shouldn't) data to inform their strategies.
This course developed my Python programming skills in a political campaign context.
This class is what made me decide to go for the stats certificate - it's what made me realize that stats is very important, even for a social sciences education.
Data science tools for politics

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
- Learning a new skill
- Compelling class time

Weaknesses: 
- Don't take this class if you think it's going to be a gut. It's not.
Kalla's great. really smart and nice. workload is never too much and exams are fair. would maybe like if lectures had a little bit more coding stuff included.
Strengths - Accessible prof and TAs during office hours, labs/problem sets were approachable, interesting applications of coding and data science to electoral campaigns
Weakness: quite a few assignments piled up with 2 midterms, a final paper, and a midterm essay in addition to the weekly psets

I think the once a week format was a large strength of the course. It made me very excited to attend each week, and I think it allowed for true engagement with the material. I also thought the problem sets were fair but also stretched our knowledge, which I think is really important. I loved this class. The only weakness was that the essays/projects were not outlined very well (they were very vague), so I think it could be helpful to add more information about these assignments.

Strengths: real-world application to the course. Prof Kalla, on the first day, said that this course would help us obtain an internship in political data analysis
Weaknesses: labs would get very long. but doable. A better system for allowing people into the course must be implemented; there were way too many people advanced in Python to be enrolled in an introductory course. Assignments overlapped to the point where we had an essay, pset, and midterm due the same day.
Very well planned out course, but not much material was covered

Strengths: lectures were thorough and providing Lab Time allowed us to get extra help when needed, labs were spaced evenly and helpful in learning difficult concepts

Weakness: The Second midterm was on an experiment with 2 treatments, something we never learned how to do in class. Given it was open-note and open-internet, I searched how to do the answer online, and they said it wasn't the way they wanted us to do it and took off a lot of points. They never taught us how to conduct the average treatment effects for these kinds of experiments, so I don't know why they expected us to calculate it in their standards.

This class was extremely interesting in learning about how the political campaigns that surround us 24/7. I also enjoyed working with real world data (e.g., analyzing the results of Pittsburgh's unique election this past year).

I think the major strength of this course comes from the fact that it's a highly marketable skill. Learning how to use python and its libraries, starts you at an advantage, should you decide to enter a data driven career/position.

Some of the strengths of this course is Professor Kalla's lectures and office hours, which make it easy to complete the weekly problem sets.

There are no weaknesses to this course.
Not well enough geared towards someone whos never coded before. Flies through the basics too fast.

The strengths of this course were learning how to code and implementing this in my usage of future career aspirations involved in understanding political campaigns and their shifts. However, the weaknesses of this course are also prominent with little teaching of code in class and limited help from the professor in understanding the code.
I think office hours could be more effective with one on one meetings.

The course was quite enriching for one with no assumed prior knowledge or material to the content. However, at times the work overlapped (i.e. a five page paper was due at the same time as a problem set which was right before a midterm.) Though this overlap created a good review prior to the exam, this felt overwhelming at times since the class' midterm periods occurred around the midterm periods of campus at large. The course also featured in-class time to work on the problem sets which allowed you to ask for help from the teaching team in real time which was invaluable as it was sort of built-in office hours.
I really enjoyed the psets and thought the midterms were helpful. However I wish we had more guidance for the final project.

This should be a course whose focus is python. Python appeared in the homework but was never taught in class. If I were in control, I would teach Python in class and then leave the readings for homework. Maybe next semester, you could do python in class and then add reading discussions to the labs.

It often felt like there was a disconnect between what we learned in class and the problem sets. I would have appreciated a little more harmony between the two -- maybe a bit of coding in class, or using the labs to dive more explicitly into a lecture topic.

This course was great! I appreciated how Professor Kalla lectured. The course was not just a data science course, but rather, incorporated the inner-workings of campaigns. It could be improved by adding a bit more data science instruction to lectures to prepare for problem sets.

Strengths: a very interesting subject. Also, Professor Kalla's research is super cool, and so it's very interesting to hear him present it.
Weaknesses:
(1) the readings did not correspond with the lectures, which did not correspond with the tests, which did not correspond with the homeworks, which did not correspond with the labs. Felt confused about the big picture of the class until Thanksgiving time
(2) The labs would have felt very hard for someone with no coding experience, and there wasn't a ton of help. Granted, I didn't go to office hours myself, but I don't think there was a lot of office hours opportunities.
(3) This class was taught like a seminar... but with 90 people. It was great that the class was made to be interactive, but at times, it felt a bit forced. I don't think this question/answer style of lecture works very well when we have as many people as we did.
Very engaging and interesting

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I took this course because I thought it would be an easy QR credit, which was not the case. However, I did learn a lot and had fun in the course, so make of that what you will.
yeah. great QR for political-minded folks.
Yes, absolutely! Even if you don't have much background in data science, the course and material are incredibly approachable.

Yes! It was a great way to get introduced to coding as someone interested in political science and campaigns - good balance of coding and content. There was, indeed, a lot of learning by doing in terms of the coding, but by the end I felt like I had the hang of it, and there was a LOT of great support in office hours, especially from Nick.
Very digestible intro stats class; great if you're a PLSC major with no coding background

I definitely would! Professor Kalla is amazing. He cares about his students so much, and he is amazing to learn from. You can tell he is very passionate about what he is teaching. I also loved the teaching fellows; they were very committed to helping me through this class!

Yes. this course provides real-world applicable skills in Python and political data analysis. For beginners in Python, it is a steep, but doable, learning curve. The TF and ULAs were incredible and approachable!

This course is great as an introduction to basic data science methods, and I would absolutely recommend it for anyone who is interested in politics and data, both in becoming a responsible consumer and producer of data.
Yes if looking for a free S&DS credit
Yes! Absolutely take for S&DS certificate
Yes, good course for learning about political campaigns and analyzing data sets.
Absolutely. This class is an incredible introduction into the intersection of data science and politics.
I would. This is a good intro to Python. And really it's a good intro to python in a field where the language is used the most.

Only if you are ready to put in the work. I think if you have never taken a single coding class, this class will teach you a lot but you have to be willing to put in the work. I think I spent more time doing labs for this class than I did on assignments for all my other classes COMBINED. The midterms were also very challenging, especially coding without your notes on the first midterm.
I would 100 percent recommend this course to other students, especially for those who are political science majors interested in campaigns or looking to fulfill a QR requirement.
Yes but its a big big challenge if you dont have coding experience
I would cautiously recommend this course to a student that has taken coding classes before with an understanding of the Python language.
Yes I would recommend this course to another student. The class was engaging and covered interesting topics that are applicable in real life.
Yes. The psets can be a little tough at times but it's a simple way to learn python if you're only interested in learning python through a political science lens.

I would recommend taking this course *if you're interested in going into politics*. Otherwise, you might find the other introduction to Python course or some other approaches such as CS50 more relevant to what you plan on doing in the future (at least in terms of building foundations).
Yes! This class was amazing and I learned a lot.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in being exposed to python. If you're looking for a rigorous review of python, I would not take this course.
Yes! If you have an interest in campaigns and politics, this is an interesting and low-workload way to get a QR.
Yes! Anyone interested in either data science or campaign work would benefit.
Yes, but I would want to go in knowing that the homework was going to be purely coding, and the lecture were going to be more theoretical.
Yes, very fun class
